Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: We are the leading global manufacturer of prime labels serving a growing blue-chip customer base across a broad range of resilient, consumer-facing end categories worldwide. We believe we have approximately 15% market share of a highly fragmented estimated $16 billion addressable market for prime labels across North America and Europe as of 2019, with approximately two times the scale of the next largest prime label manufacturer and approximately seven times the scale of the third and fourth largest prime label manufacturers, respectively, based on net sales for 2019. We aspire to deliver industry-leading products, services and expertise through our experienced associates and seamless customer experience. This aspiration drives us and is reflected in the customer and market focus, teamwork, process excellence and trusted relationships that define our culture. We believe our scale and global footprint, comprehensive product and service offering, welldiversified exposures, long-standing customer relationships and dedicated employees, significant expected cost savings opportunities, meaningful investments in innovation and sustainability solutions, and extensive acquisition track record create competitive advantages relative to other prime label manufacturers. We believe MCC and Fort Dearborn are highly complementary businesses and that the combination is strategically and financially compelling, resulting in a stronger market leader in a highly fragmented industry in which scale provides advantages. The combination will expand the breadth and depth of our comprehensive product portfolio and customer base, across which there is limited overlap, and will improve our diversification across label technologies, end categories and geographies. Our comprehensive portfolio of label technologies, including Pressure Sensitive, Cut & Stack, Roll-Fed, In-Mold, Shrink Sleeve and Heat Transfer, serves approximately 16,000 aggregate customers across a broad range of end categories, including Food & Beverage, Wine & Spirits, Home & Personal Care and Healthcare, Industrial & Other Specialty.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: On a combined basis, we are the leading global manufacturer of prime labels. We believe that we have approximately 15% market share across North America and Europe, with approximately two 116 ----- times the scale of the next largest prime label manufacturer and approximately seven times the scale of the third and fourth largest prime label manufacturers, respectively, based on net sales. Further, we believe that we hold number one or number two positions in each of the key label technologies and end categories we serve across North America and Europe. The global prime labels industry remains highly fragmented, with single plant manufacturers operating in a local market, or multi-plant manufacturers operating in certain regions, constituting the majority of industry capacity, with relatively few global manufacturers. We believe our leading global position and scale in a highly fragmented industry provide meaningful advantages in comparison with smaller national, regional and local competitors. These advantages span procurement and sourcing, operational efficiency and commercial/organic growth. Our combined scale affords us with advantaged buying power vis-à-vis our base of suppliers and unlocks volume discounts for certain spend categories. We believe the principal competitive factors for the global prime labels market include local selling capabilities, availability, breadth and cost of materials and supplies, technical knowledge and expertise, value-add service capabilities, customer and supplier relationships, reliability and accuracy of service, product performance, effective use of technology, technology leadership, delivery capabilities and timeliness, pricing of products and the provision of credit. We believe that our key strengths and strategy allow us to compete effectively in our markets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We benefit from strong, enduring relationships with our customers, ranging from the largest global consumer packaged goods (“CPG”) companies to smaller CPG companies. We have a diverse customer base consisting of approximately 16,000 customers. Our customers include a wide range of consumer product companies, and we supply labels for many of the world’s best-known brands and products. The customer relationships of MCC and Fort Dearborn are highly complementary due to limited customer overlap, and the combined company will have no meaningful customer concentration, as our top customer represented only approximately 5% of combined net revenues for the LTM Period. Our differentiated value proposition has resulted in long-tenured relationships with our top ten customers of greater than 25 years on average, and we believe significant opportunities exist to increase share-of-wallet with existing customers while acquiring new customers. We continue to monitor and analyze new trends in the packaging and consumer products industries to ensure that we are providing appropriate services and products to our customers. Certain factors that influence our business include consumer spending, new product introductions, new packaging technologies and demographics.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Realization of Expected Synergies after the Transactions
Subsubsection Text: Following the consummation of the Transactions, we intend to apply best practices and leverage our enhanced scale across MCC and Fort Dearborn to drive additional growth and share gain, enhance operational performance and profitability and improve capital efficiency. We estimate that the combination will unlock approximately $150 million of run-rate cost synergies. The cost synergies are expected to be driven primarily by procurement savings, efficiencies in selling, general, and administrative expense, manufacturing footprint consolidation and operational improvements including material waste reduction and in-sourcing, among others. In addition to the identified cost synergies, we believe there are several other meaningful operational improvement opportunities, as reflected by approximately $84 million of “in-flight” cost savings initiatives identified by management across the combined business, expected to be driven by cost synergy realization from previously completed acquisitions, continuous improvement and lean manufacturing, procurement, capital productivity and other identified initiatives. 117 ----- We also expect to incur costs in connection with such activities, including severance payments, IT system integration costs and other associated costs. There can be no assurance that any such activities will ultimately be undertaken and, if so, whether such efforts will result in the expected cost benefits, if any.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The COVID-19 pandemic has introduced a period of unprecedented uncertainty and challenge. Our operations have been largely recognized as “essential” by governments and authorities around the world given the role we play in the supply chains for critical food and healthcare products. Our scale and global footprint has enabled us to collaborate with customers and suppliers to meet volatile changes in demand and continue to service our customers. Our facilities have largely been exempted from government mandated closure orders and while governmental measures may be modified, we expect that our operations will remain operational given the essential products we supply. However, despite our best efforts to contain the impact in our facilities, it remains possible that significant disruptions could occur as a result of the pandemic, including temporary closures of our facilities. We cannot reasonably estimate the duration and severity of this pandemic or its ultimate impact on the global economy and our operations and financial results. The ultimate near-term impact of the pandemic on our business will depend on the extent and nature of any future disruptions across the supply chain, the duration of social distancing measures and other government imposed restrictions and the nature and pace of macroeconomic recovery in key global economies.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our operating results will be influenced by a broad range of factors, including those outlined below.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: After the closing of the Transactions, we will have substantial indebtedness. As of June 30, 2021, on a pro forma combined basis, after giving effect to the Transactions, we would have had total indebtedness of $4,657.4 million, including $1,390.0 million of MCC Existing Notes, $1,210.0 million of Notes offered hereby, $1,971.8 million of borrowings under the Senior Term Loan Facility. In addition, we expect to have the ability to draw an initial aggregate principal amount of $200.0 million under the 118 ----- Senior Cash Flow Revolving Credit Facility and $500.0 million under the Senior ABL Revolving Credit Facility (subject to borrowing base limitations), under which we estimate that we will have approximately $7.31 million of letters of credit outstanding at the closing of the Transactions, based on Australian dollar to U.S. dollar and Euro to U.S. dollar conversion rates on October 1, 2021. Actual amounts of such other indebtedness outstanding upon the closing of the Transactions may vary. Our liquidity requirements will be significant, primarily due to our debt service requirements. On a pro forma combined basis, after giving effect to the Transactions, our cash interest expense for the last twelve months ended June 30, 2021 would have been $148.5 million for our Senior Term Loan Facility and the Notes offered hereby.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: As of June 30, 2021, on a pro forma combined basis, after giving effect to the Transactions, we expect to have borrowings under the Senior Term Loan Facility in an aggregate principal amount of $1,971.8 million (as further described in “Description of Other Indebtedness—Senior Cash Flow Credit Facilities”). As of June 30, 2021, on a pro forma combined basis, we expect to have availability for future borrowings under the Senior Cash Flow Revolving Credit Facility in an aggregate principal amount of $200.0 million (as further described in “Description of Other Indebtedness—Senior Cash Flow Credit Facilities”). We do not expect to draw on the Senior Cash Flow Revolving Credit Facility as of the closing date of the Transactions in order to fund the combined purchase price, although we may draw on the facility to fund working capital or for other uses. In addition, we may draw on the Senior Cash Flow Revolving Credit Facility in the future for general corporate purposes, including for working capital.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: As of June 30, 2021, on a pro forma combined basis, we expect to have availability for future borrowings under the Senior ABL Revolving Credit Facility in an aggregate principal amount of up to $500.0 million (as further described in “Description of Other Indebtedness—Senior ABL Revolving Credit Facility”). We do not expect to draw on the Senior ABL Revolving Credit Facility as of the closing date of the Transactions in order to fund the combined purchase price, although we may draw on the facility to fund working capital or for other uses. In addition, we may draw on the Senior ABL Revolving Credit Facility in the future for general corporate purposes, including for working capital.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: Upon the closing of the MCC Acquisition, the Issuer will remain bound by its obligations in relation to the 2019 issuance and sale of $700.0 million aggregate principal amount of 6.75% MCC 2026 Notes due 2026 and the 2019 issuance and sale of $690.0 million aggregate principal amount of 10.50% MCC 2027 Notes due 2027. Each of the MCC Existing Indentures contain customary affirmative and negative covenants. The negative covenants include limitations on indebtedness, dividends, distributions and other restricted payments, issuing disqualified stock, asset sales, transactions with affiliates, liens and in the case of the MCC 2026 Indenture, LABL Midco engaging in any business other than the ownership of capital stock of and management of the Issuer. 119 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: The indentures that will govern the Notes offered hereby will contain certain covenants, agreements and events of default that are customary with respect to non-investment grade debt securities, including limitations on mergers, consolidations, sale of substantially all of our assets, incurrence of indebtedness, restricted payments, liens and affiliate transactions by us or our restricted subsidiaries. The terms of the Notes will require us to make an offer to repay the Notes upon a change of control or upon certain asset sales. The terms of the indenture will also significantly restrict us and our restricted subsidiaries from paying dividends and otherwise transferring assets. For more information, see “Description of Secured Notes” and “Description of Unsecured Notes.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: Our primary sources of liquidity will be our cash and cash equivalents, cash flows from operations and borrowings under our Senior Cash Flow Revolving Credit Facility and Senior ABL Revolving Credit Facility. We believe that these sources will provide sufficient liquidity for us to meet our working capital, capital expenditure and other cash requirements for the foreseeable future. We believe that the costs associated with implementing our business strategy and the integration of MCC and Fort Dearborn will not materially impact our liquidity. The performance of our business is significantly impacted by consumer consumption of the products sold in the packages or with the inserts and labels we produce, which is sensitive to general business and economic conditions in the U.S. and worldwide. Any unforeseen or unanticipated economic downturn could have a negative impact on our liquidity position. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—Our business performance may be impacted by general economic conditions, including downturns in the geographies and target markets that we serve.” Our business may not be able to generate sufficient cash flow from operations, or future borrowings may not be available to meet our liquidity needs. We anticipate that to the extent that we require additional liquidity as a result of these factors or in order to execute our strategy, we would be financed either by borrowings under our new Cash Flow Credit Agreement, by other indebtedness, equity financings or a combination of the foregoing. However, we may be unable to obtain any such additional financing on reasonable terms or at all.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: As of June 30, 2021, on a pro forma combined basis, we had contractual obligations and commitments consisting principally of long-term debt, representing the Senior Cash Flow Credit Facilities, the MCC Existing Notes and the Notes and interest obligations with respect to that long-term debt. Subsequent to June 30, 2021, other than as contemplated by the Transactions, there have been no material changes to our contractual obligations that are outside the normal course.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: We did not have any material off-balance sheet arrangements as of June 30, 2021 or December 31, 2020.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: We will be exposed to changes in interest rates following the Transactions. To the extent LIBOR exceeds 0.00%, our indebtedness under the Senior Cash Flow Credit Facilities and the Senior ABL Revolving Credit Facility will bear interest, and our future indebtedness may bear interest, at variable rates. As a result, increases in interest rates would increase the cost of servicing such debt and could materially reduce our profitability and cash flows. As of June 30, 2021, assuming all Senior Cash Flow Revolving Credit Facility and Senior ABL Revolving Credit Facility revolving loans were fully drawn and LIBOR exceeded 0.50%, each 0.125 percentage point change in interest rates would result in approximately a $0.9 million change in annual interest expense on the Senior Cash Flow Credit Facilities and the Senior ABL Revolving Credit Facility. We may manage our exposure to fluctuations in interest rates following the consummation of the Transactions with respect to our new Senior Cash Flow Credit Facilities and the Senior ABL Revolving Credit Facility by entering into certain market-based interest rate hedging instruments, such as swaps or caps.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: Foreign currency exchange risk arises from our international operations as well as from transactions with customers or suppliers denominated in currencies other than the U.S. dollar. The functional currency of each of our subsidiaries is generally the currency of the country in which the subsidiary operates or the 120 ----- U.S. dollar. The results of operations of our foreign subsidiaries are translated into U.S. dollars at the average exchange rate for each monthly period. As foreign exchange rates change, there are changes to the U.S. dollar equivalent of sales and expenses denominated in foreign currencies. Unfavorable movements in exchange rates between the U.S. dollar and Canadian dollar and other foreign currencies may have an adverse impact on our reported results. These exchange rate movements could create a foreign currency gain or loss that could be realized or unrealized for us. We may enter into certain market-based hedging instruments, such as forward contracts or purchase option agreements, to hedge foreign currency risks. Historically, MCC has entered into foreign exchange forward contracts to fix the purchase price in U.S. dollars of foreign currency denominated raw materials. These forward contracts have been designated as cash flow hedges with gains and losses, net of tax, measured on an ongoing basis, recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income (loss).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: The primary raw materials that we use are paper and ink. To reduce price risk caused by market fluctuations, we may incorporate price adjustment clauses in certain sales contracts. We do not believe that changes in the price of paper and other raw materials will have a material effect on our consolidated annual results of operations or cash flows because these costs are generally passed through to our customers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to credit risk on accounts receivable balances. This risk is mitigated due to our large, diverse customer base, dispersed over various geographic regions and industrial sectors. We intend to maintain provisions for potential credit losses and evaluate the solvency of our customers on an ongoing basis to determine if additional allowances for doubtful accounts receivable need to be recorded. Significant economic disruptions or a slowdown in the economy could result in additional charges.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: We test goodwill for impairment by comparing the estimated fair value of the reporting units to the related carrying value. If the fair value of the reporting unit is lower than its carrying amount, goodwill is written down for the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds fair value. However, the loss recognized cannot exceed the carrying amount of goodwill. Reporting units are defined as either 121 ----- operating segments or one level below the operating segments for which discrete financial information is available and reviewed by the business management. When performing our interim and annual impairment assessments, we estimate the fair value of reporting units using a combination of: (i) a market approach based on multiples of net revenues and earnings before interest depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) from recent comparable transactions and other market data; and (ii) an income approach based on expected future cash flows discounted at rates ranging between 9.00% to 12.75%. Significant assumptions inherent in the valuation methodologies include estimates of future projected business results (principally net revenues and EBITDA), long-term growth rates, and the discount rate. The discount rate reflects the risk associated with each respective reporting unit, including the industry and geographies in which they operate. The discount rate may be impacted by adverse changes in the macroeconomic environment, specifically the COVID-19 pandemic, our ability to achieve our most recent forecasts, and other factors not known at this time. Discounted cash flow models are highly reliant on various assumptions, including projected business results, long-term growth factors and discount rate. Management judgement is involved in estimating these variables, and they include inherent uncertainties since they are forecasting future events. We perform sensitivity analyses by using a range of inputs to confirm the reasonableness of the long-term growth rate and discount rate estimates. These assumptions are typically not considered individually because assumptions used to select one variable should also be considered when selecting other variables; however, sensitivity of the overall fair value assessment to each significant variable is also considered.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to income taxes in the United States and numerous foreign jurisdictions. The provision for income taxes includes income taxes paid, currently payable or receivable, and deferred taxes. Under U.S. GAAP, deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on differences between financial reporting and tax basis of assets and liabilities and are measured using enacted tax rates and laws that are expected to be in effect when the differences reverse. Deferred tax assets are also recognized for the estimated future effects of tax loss and credit carryforwards. The effect on deferred taxes of changes in tax rates is recognized in the period in which the enactment date occurs. Valuation allowances are established when necessary on a jurisdictional basis to reduce deferred tax assets to the amounts expected to be realized. Deferred taxes are not provided on the unremitted earnings of subsidiaries outside of the United States when it is expected that these earnings are indefinitely reinvested. In the event that the actual outcome of future tax consequences differs from our estimates and assumptions due to changes or future events such as tax legislation, geographic mix of earnings, completion of tax audits or earnings repatriation plans, the resulting change to the provision for income taxes could have a material effect on the consolidated statement of operations and the consolidated balance sheet. The recoverability of deferred tax assets and the recognition and measurement of uncertain tax positions are subject to various assumptions and judgment. If actual results differ from the estimates made by us in establishing or maintaining valuation allowances against deferred tax assets, the resulting change in the valuation allowance would generally impact earnings. Additionally, the positions taken with regard to tax contingencies may be subject to audit and review by tax authorities, which may result in future taxes, interest and penalties. Positive and negative evidence is considered in determining the need for a valuation allowance against deferred tax assets, which includes such evidence as historical earnings, projected future earnings, tax planning strategies and expected timing of reversal of existing temporary differences. In determining the recoverability of deferred tax assets, we give consideration to all available positive and negative evidence including reversals of deferred tax liabilities and recent trends in financial results. In evaluating the objective evidence that historical results provide, we generally consider three years of cumulative income or loss at the jurisdictional taxpayer level as an important factor. 122 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: We continue to monitor the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic to assess the outlook for demand of our products and the impact on our business and financial performance. The potential impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on demand, production levels, and our operating results in the short-term is uncertain, but we remain committed to the strategic actions necessary to realize long-term revenue and cash flow growth rates. The potential effect of negative demand on net revenues is also uncertain given the volatile environment, but demand and production levels are anticipated to recover. Future changes in the judgments, assumptions and estimates that are used in the impairment testing for goodwill, including discount and tax rates or future cash flow projections, could result in significantly different estimates of the fair values. While we can implement and have implemented certain strategies to address these events, changes in operating plans, forecasts, or adverse changes in the future could reduce the underlying cash flows used to estimate each of our reporting unit fair values and could result in a further decline in fair value that would trigger a future material non-cash impairment charge of the reporting units’ goodwill balance in future periods. 123 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of consolidated financial statements requires us to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses. We continually evaluate our estimates, including, but not limited to, those related to operating lease assets and liabilities, revenue recognition, bad debts, business consolidations, inventories and any related reserves, income taxes, fixed assets, goodwill and intangible assets. We base our estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions believed to be reasonable under the facts and circumstances. Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions. We believe that the following accounting estimates are critical to our financial results:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMBINED COMPANY
Subsubsection Text: _The following discussion should be read in conjunction with LABL’s and FD’s respective historical consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this offering circular. The discussion and analysis of historical periods herein does not reflect the significant impact that the Transactions will have on us, including significantly increased leverage and liquidity requirements. See “—Liquidity and Capital Resources” below for a discussion of new indebtedness that we expect to incur. In addition to historical information, the following discussion contains forward looking information that involves risks and uncertainties. Our actual results could differ materially from those anticipated by this forward looking information due to factors discussed under the section entitled “Risk Factors” and elsewhere in this offering circular. See “Cautionary Note Regarding Forward Looking Statements.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF LABL
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading global provider of label solutions supporting a number of the world’s most prominent brands including leading producers of Food & Beverage, Wine & Spirits, Home & Personal Care and Healthcare, Industrial & Other Specialty. We serve international brand owners in North America, South America, Europe, Africa, Australia, New Zealand and the Asia Pacific region with a comprehensive range of the latest label technologies in Pressure Sensitive, In-Mold, Cut and Stack, Shrink Sleeve, Heat Transfer and Roll Fed. Our headquarters are in Batavia, Ohio. On February 5, 2018, LABL Midco acquired 100% of the outstanding capital stock of W/S Packaging Holdings, Inc. via a reverse triangular merger of WS Labels Merger Corporation, a whollyowned subsidiary of LABL Midco, with and into W/S Packaging Holdings, Inc., with W/S Packaging Holdings, Inc. as the surviving entity. Effective as of June 3, 2019, W/S Packaging Holdings, Inc. was renamed LABL, Inc. On July 1, 2019, LABL acquired Multi-Color Corporation and the business was merged with LABL (the “Multi-Color Acquisition”). Results for the twelve months ended December 31, 2020 and 2019 and the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020 include results of the merged businesses of LABL and Multi-Color Corporation (the “merged businesses”), in the case of the twelve months ended December 31, 2019, from July 1, 2019. On March 31, 2021, LABL acquired 100% of John Herrod and Associates Pty Ltd (“Herrods”), located in Melbourne, Australia, for $19,826 plus net debt assumed of $3,042. Herrods, a leading producer of In-Mold labels in Australia and New Zealand, allows LABL to expand its In-Mold label footprint in the Asia Pacific region and complements LABL’s existing In-Mold label business currently in Europe and the U.S. On September 30, 2021, LABL acquired Hexagon, a leading manufacturer of prime labels in Australia and New Zealand with $133,259 in revenue and $31,804 in Adjusted EBITDA as of the LTM Period. On September 30, 2021, LABL also announced it had entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Skanem, a leading provider of prime labels in Northern Europe and Thailand with $123,309 in net revenues and $16,856 in Adjusted EBITDA as of the LTM Period. The transaction is expected to close during the fourth quarter of 2021. For additional information, see “Offering Circular Summary— Recent Developments.” 124 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF LABL
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Key factors that have influenced our results of operations and may do so in the future are described under “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of the Combined Company—Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF LABL
Subsubsection Text: Net revenues are primarily generated from the sale of prime labels to external customers, reduced for customer credits, sales returns and allowances, earned early payment discounts, and earned customer rebates. Net revenues can be impacted by our customers’ production and marketing cycles, particularly in the areas of promotional and coupon applications, whose run dates can vary year to year. The end categories served include F&B, CPG and Specialty, which tend to provide a generally stable base of sales from quarter to quarter. Net revenues are generally not seasonal.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF LABL
Subsubsection Text: Our expenses primarily consist of: Cost of revenues._ Cost of revenues includes raw materials (primarily paper and ink), cores, cartons, labor and benefits, production supplies, parts and repairs, rents, utilities, freight, and other direct and indirect costs associated with the manufacturing process. Cost of goods sold is generally driven by the cost of these items and the volume and mix of the products manufactured. Gross profit._ Gross profit primarily represents the difference between the product cost, including labor and indirect costs associated with the manufacturing process, and the sale price to our customers. Selling, general and administrative._ These expenses include salaries and commissions for corporate and sales personnel, marketing expenses, professional fees, legal and consulting fees, bad debt expense and other corporate administrative costs not allocated to cost of products sold. Selling, general, and administrative expenses are primarily driven by wage increases, the occurrence and timing of consulting projects, and other legal and professional fees, offset by headcount reductions. Facility closure._ Facility closure expenses primarily include severance, contract termination and other associated costs (including, but not limited to costs to consolidate or close facilities and relocate employees). Transaction, integration and restructuring._ Transaction, integration and restructuring costs primarily include direct costs related to acquisition of businesses, integration of acquisitions into our existing operations and restructuring of operations. These costs include legal, accounting, valuation, engineering, finders’ fees, severance, contract termination costs and other associated costs. Amortization expense and impairment loss on intangible assets._ We record amortization of identifiable intangible assets on a straight-line basis over the contractual or estimated useful life of each intangible asset. Identifiable intangible assets are reviewed for impairment whenever events or circumstances indicate the carrying amount of the asset may not be fully recoverable. When the carrying value of an asset exceeds its fair value, an impairment loss is recognized. 125 ----- Interest expense._ Interest expense includes interest accruing on our indebtedness, including capital leases. Interest expense is affected by changes in average outstanding indebtedness and variable interest rates. Other expense (income)._ Other income includes proceeds from the sale of scrap and rental income collected on properties sub-leased subsequent to operational restructurings. Other income also includes the gains and losses resulting from foreign currency transaction adjustments. Other income is primarily driven by scrap values. Loss on extinguishment of debt._ Loss on extinguishment of debt primarily represents losses incurred to extinguish certain debt and related debt issuance costs, including senior notes and bonds. Income tax expense._ Income taxes include current taxes payable or refundable, plus or minus the change during the period in deferred tax assets and liabilities.

Subsubsection Text: Net revenues . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . $2,097,739 $1,261,519 $836,220 66.3% Net revenues were $2,097,739 for the twelve months ended December 31, 2020 compared to $1,261,519 in the prior year. The net revenues increase was primarily due to the Multi-Color Acquisition on July 1, 2019. As a result of the mid-year acquisition in 2019, Multi-Color provided an increase of $856,425 of net revenues during the twelve months ended 2020 in comparison to the prior year. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF LABL
Subsubsection Text: Historically, our liquidity requirements have principally been the payment of operating expenses, capital expenditures and scheduled principal and interest payments on our indebtedness. We have historically funded these liquidity requirements primarily from cash generated by our operations and borrowings under our credit facilities. 131 ----- Our primary sources of liquidity at June 30, 2021 were (i) $45.1 million in unrestricted cash and cash equivalents and (ii) unused committed debt facilities of up to $234.7 million from a revolving bank line of credit facility expiring in July 2024. In connection with the Transactions, all amounts outstanding (other than contingent obligations) on the closing date of the Transactions under (i) the Term Loan Credit Agreement, dated July 1, 2019, (as amended by the Amendment No.1 To Term Loan Credit Agreement dated February 9, 2021) among LABL Acquisition Corporation, LABL, Inc., the other subsidiary borrowers party thereto from time to time, the lenders party thereto from time to time and Bank of America, N.A. and (ii) the Revolving Credit Agreement (as amended by the Amendment No.1 To Revolving Credit Agreement dated September 25, 2019 and Amendment No.2 To Revolving Credit Agreement dated February 13, 2020), dated July 1, 2019, among LABL Acquisition Corporation, LABL, Inc., the other borrowers party thereto from time to time, the lenders party thereto and Bank of America, N.A., will be repaid, redeemed, defeased, terminated or otherwise discharged (or notice for the repayment, redemption, defeasance, termination or discharge thereof will be given). Upon the closing of the Transactions, LABL will remain bound by its obligations in relation to the MCC Existing Notes. Our long-term needs primarily include meeting debt service requirements, working capital requirements, and capital expenditures. Our ability to service our indebtedness and to fund our other liquidity requirements will depend on our ability to generate and access cash in the future. This is subject to general economic, financial, contractual, competitive, legislative, regulatory and other factors, some of which are beyond our control, as well as the factors described in “Risk Factors.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF LABL
Subsubsection Text: We test goodwill for impairment by comparing the estimated fair value of the reporting units to the related carrying value. If the fair value of the reporting unit is lower than its carrying amount, goodwill is written down for the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds fair value. However, the loss recognized cannot exceed the carrying amount of goodwill. Reporting units are defined as either operating segments or one level below the operating segments for which discrete financial information is available and reviewed by the business management. When performing our interim and annual impairment assessments, we estimate the fair value of reporting units using a combination of: (i) a market approach based on multiples of net revenues and earnings before interest depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) from recent comparable transactions and other market data; and (ii) an income approach based on expected future cash flows discounted at rates ranging between 9.00% to 12.75%. Significant assumptions inherent in the valuation methodologies include estimates of future projected business results (principally net revenues and EBITDA), long-term growth rates, and the discount rate. The discount rate reflects the risk associated with each respective reporting unit, including the industry and geographies in which they operate. The discount rate may be impacted by adverse changes in the macroeconomic environment, specifically the COVID-19 pandemic, our ability to achieve our most recent forecasts, and other factors not known at this time. Discounted cash flow models are highly reliant on various assumptions, including projected business results, long-term growth factors and discount rate. Management judgement is involved in estimating these variables, and they include inherent uncertainties since they are forecasting future events. We perform sensitivity analyses by using a range of inputs to confirm the reasonableness of the long-term growth rate and discount rate estimates. These assumptions are typically not considered individually because assumptions used to select one variable should also be considered when selecting other variables; however, sensitivity of the overall fair value assessment to each significant variable is also considered.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF LABL
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to income taxes in the United States and numerous foreign jurisdictions. The provision for income taxes includes income taxes paid, currently payable or receivable, and deferred taxes. Under GAAP, deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on differences between financial reporting and tax basis of assets and liabilities and are measured using enacted tax rates and laws that are expected to be in effect when the differences reverse. Deferred tax assets are also recognized for the estimated future effects of tax loss and credit carryforwards. The effect on deferred taxes of changes in tax rates is recognized in the period in which the enactment date occurs. Valuation allowances are established when necessary on a jurisdictional basis to reduce deferred tax assets to the amounts expected to be realized. Deferred taxes are not provided on the unremitted earnings of 133 ----- subsidiaries outside of the United States when it is expected that these earnings are indefinitely reinvested. In the event that the actual outcome of future tax consequences differs from our estimates and assumptions due to changes or future events such as tax legislation, geographic mix of earnings, completion of tax audits or earnings repatriation plans, the resulting change to the provision for income taxes could have a material effect on the consolidated statement of operations and the consolidated balance sheet. The recoverability of deferred tax assets and the recognition and measurement of uncertain tax positions are subject to various assumptions and judgment. If actual results differ from the estimates made by us in establishing or maintaining valuation allowances against deferred tax assets, the resulting change in the valuation allowance would generally impact earnings. Additionally, the positions taken with regard to tax contingencies may be subject to audit and review by tax authorities, which may result in future taxes, interest and penalties. Positive and negative evidence is considered in determining the need for a valuation allowance against deferred tax assets, which includes such evidence as historical earnings, projected future earnings, tax planning strategies and expected timing of reversal of existing temporary differences. In determining the recoverability of deferred tax assets, we give consideration to all available positive and negative evidence including reversals of deferred tax liabilities and recent trends in financial results. In evaluating the objective evidence that historical results provide, we generally consider three years of cumulative income or loss at the jurisdictional taxpayer level as an important factor.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF LABL
Subsubsection Text: We continue to monitor the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic to assess the outlook for demand of our products and the impact on our business and financial performance. The potential impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on demand, production levels, and our operating results in the short-term is uncertain, but we remain committed to the strategic actions necessary to realize long-term net revenues and cash flow growth rates. The potential effect of negative demand on net revenues is also uncertain given the volatile environment, but demand and production levels are anticipated to recover. Future changes in the judgments, assumptions and estimates that are used in the impairment testing for goodwill, including discount and tax rates or future cash flow projections, could result in significantly different estimates of the fair values. While we can implement and have implemented certain strategies to address these events, changes in operating plans, forecasts, or adverse changes in the future could reduce the underlying cash flows used to estimate each of our reporting unit fair values and could result in a further decline in fair value that would trigger a future material non-cash impairment charge of the reporting units’ goodwill balance in future periods.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FORT DEARBORN
Subsubsection Text: Fort Dearborn is a leading supplier of decorative product labels to a wide variety of end categories. Headquartered in Elk Grove Village, Illinois, Fort Dearborn has no additional operations outside of its primary operating subsidiary, Fort Dearborn Company, which has 20 label manufacturing facilities strategically located throughout the United States and Canada. Fort Dearborn manufactures and sells labels for use primarily by the food, beverage, wine & spirits, paint industries and other consumer products. Fort Dearborn’s products are used by a variety of companies and industries across the consumer products markets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FORT DEARBORN
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic on our Business
Subsubsection Text: The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted, and is likely to continue to result, in significant economic disruption, and will likely continue to affect our business. During 2020, we experienced increased demand resulting in higher sales associated with the COVID-19 pandemic. The increased sales were mostly offset by higher outsourcing costs, material and labor shortages and other various plant costs associated with the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result, our liquidity was not materially impacted by the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result of COVID-19, both the public and private sectors in the United States and in other affected regions have introduced certain policies and initiatives in an effort to reduce the transmission 135 ----- of COVID-19, such as the imposition of travel restrictions; mandates from federal, state and local authorities to close non-essential businesses and avoid large gatherings of people; quarantine or “shelter-in-place;” and the promotion of social distancing and the adoption of work-from-home and online learning by companies and institutions. For the six months ended June 30, 2021, Fort Dearborn experienced moderate negative financial impact due to the COVID-19 pandemic, as our customers were impacted by various factors related to the pandemic such as “shelter-in-place,” “stay-at-home” orders and travel restrictions. Fort Dearborn’s plants have generally remained operational, although some slowdowns associated with raw materials and labor market shortages and outsourcing of certain activities created additional costs and inefficiencies for Fort Dearborn. We have continued to service our customers without disruption during 2021. We will continue to actively monitor the situation, particularly in light of the recent surge associated with the COVID-19 delta variant and may take actions that alter our business operations as may be required by federal, state or local authorities or that we determine are in the best interests of our employees, customers and suppliers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FORT DEARBORN
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We look to complement our organic growth via select acquisitions that allow us to broaden our product offering, geographic footprint and service capabilities. In accordance with the acquisition method of accounting under Accounting Standards Codification (“ASC”) 805, “Business Combinations,” the results of the acquisitions which we have completed are reflected in Fort Dearborn’s consolidated financial statements from the date of the acquisition forward. On October 8, 2019, we purchased a majority of the assets and the liabilities of Walle Corporation (“Walle”), a manufacturer of printed labels, principally for the food, beverage and household product industries, for total consideration of $17.7 million, comprising an initial consideration of $15.8 million, with a post-closing working capital adjustment of $1.8 million. On February 2, 2020, we purchased a majority of the assets and the liabilities of The Oak Printing Company, a producer of printed labels principally for the food, beverage and household product industries, for total consideration of $5.0 million. On March 1, 2021, we acquired 100% of the issued stock of Hammer Packaging Corporation (“Hammer”) for a base purchase price of approximately $101.0 million. The Hammer transaction is subject to customary representations and warranties, holdbacks and a net working capital adjustment. The acquisition of Hammer was funded through the issuance of new term debt of $90.0 million and a capital contribution of $20.0 million. Hammer is a producer of diverse packaging solutions with innovative technological capabilities and robust research and development resources, with a manufacturing footprint that serves the North American market.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FORT DEARBORN
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Business and Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We operate in a highly fragmented and competitive market and hold a leading position in the premium labels market in North America. The majority of our competition comes from mid-sized and small label suppliers; however, we also face competition from a number of North American and global label suppliers. 136 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FORT DEARBORN
Subsubsection Text: We earn revenue primarily from the manufacturing of products customized for our customers. The majority of our revenue, including product and equipment sales, is recognized at a point in time based on shipments to our customer. Certain customers may receive volume-based incentives, which we account for as variable consideration and estimate these amounts based on the expected amount to be provided to customers and reduce revenue recognized. Some of our customers receive a portion of their products as consigned inventories with revenue recognized once the customer uses or consumes the products. Revenue recognized over time, related to contracts, including consignment and vendor managed inventory arrangements, with customers for products that do not have an alternative use, includes a reasonable profit throughout the duration of the contract and contains enforceable right of payment terms. The amount of revenue recognized is based on the consideration to which we expect to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services upon completion of manufacturing, including the expected value of variable consideration, based on the completion percentage of products. Taxes assessed by a government authority that are both imposed on and concurrent with a specific revenue-producing transaction, that we collect from our customer, are excluded from sales.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FORT DEARBORN
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF FORT DEARBORN
Subsubsection Text: Our primary sources of liquidity at June 30, 2021 were (i) $3.2 million in cash and cash equivalents and (ii) unused committed debt facilities of up to $30.3 million from a revolving line of credit first lien credit facility expiring in July 2023. In connection with the Transactions, all amounts outstanding (other than contingent obligations) on the closing date of the Transactions under (i) the First Lien Credit Agreement, dated October 19, 2016 (as amended by the First Amendment dated January 2, 2018, the Second Amendment dated October 10, 2019, the Third Amendment dated October 20, 2020 and the Fourth Amendment, dated March 1, 2021), Fortress Intermediate, Inc., Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc., the lenders party thereto, Deutsche Bank Securities Inc., Golub Capital LLC and Deutsche Bank AG New York Branch, and (ii) the Second Lien Credit Agreement, dated October 19, 2016, among Fortress Intermediate, Inc., Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc., the lenders party thereto, Deutsche Bank AG New York Branch, Deutsche Bank Securities Inc., Citigroup Global Markets Inc., RBC Capital Markets and Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC, will be repaid, redeemed, defeased or otherwise discharged. Our long-term needs primarily include meeting debt service requirements, working capital requirements and capital expenditures. We may also pursue strategic acquisition opportunities that may impact our future cash requirements. There are a number of factors that may negatively impact our available sources of funds in the future including the ability to generate cash from operations and borrow on our debt facilities. The amount of cash generated from operations is dependent upon factors such as the successful execution of our business strategies and general economic conditions. The amount of cash available for borrowings under our various debt facilities is dependent on our ability to maintain sufficient collateral and general financial conditions in the marketplace. Our cash requirements within the next twelve months primarily include accounts payable and accrued liabilities, current maturities of long-term debt, other current liabilities, and purchase commitments and other obligations. We expect the cash required to meet these obligations to be primarily generated through a combination of cash from operations, our revolving line of credit and access to capital through our shareholders. 142 ----- Our long-term cash requirements under our various contractual obligations and commitments include: - Debt Obligations and Interest Payments—See Note 8, “Revolving Line of Credit and LongTerm Debt,” in Fort Dearborn’s consolidated financial statements as of December 31, 2020 for further detail of our debt and the timing of expected future principal and interest payments; - Operating and Capital leases—See Note 9, “Leases,” in Fort Dearborn’s consolidated financial statements as of December 31, 2020 for further detail of our obligations and the timing of expected future payments; - Employee Benefit Plans—See Note 12, “Benefit Plans,” in Fort Dearborn’s consolidated financial statements as of December 31, 2020 for further detail of our obligations and the timing of expected future payments under the US Benefit Plans and Canadian Benefit Plans; and - Interest Rate Swap—See Note 1 (m), “Derivatives,” in Fort Dearborn’s consolidated financial statements as of December 31, 2020 for further detail of our obligations and the timing of expected future payments. We believe the following sources will be sufficient to meet our anticipated cash requirements for at least the next twelve months, while maintaining sufficient liquidity for normal operating purposes: - our cash flows from operations; - the availability of additional capital under our existing revolving line of credit; - our ability to access additional capital through the issuance of new term debt under our first lien term loan credit facility; and - our ability to access capital privately through our shareholders and other institutional investors. Due to our strong financial position, we believe that we will continue to be able to effectively access capital through long-term capital markets, if necessary.
