The Company’s expense from income taxes was $47,920 and $8,933 for the three months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, respectively. The effective tax rate was (447.1)% and (66.6)% for the three months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, respectively. The Company’s expense from income taxes was $16,190 and $8,219 for the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, respectively. The effective tax rate was (69.4)% and (37.8)% for the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, respectively. Income tax expense was $47,920 in the current year period compared to $8,933 in the prior year period primarily due to a valuation allowance recorded against United States (U.S.) interest disallowance carryforward and an increase in the United Kingdom (UK) corporate tax rate from 19% to 25%. For the three and six months ended June 30, 2021, the difference between the effective tax rate and the federal statutory tax rate relates to (i) exclusion of losses from jurisdictions in which no tax benefit is expected to be recognized, (ii) a valuation allowance recorded related to the limitation on the deductibility of interest and (iii) state taxes. For the three and six months ended June 30, 2020, the difference between the effective tax rate and the federal statutory tax rate relates to (i) exclusion of losses from jurisdictions in which no tax benefit is expected to be recognized, (ii) a valuation allowance recorded related to the limitation on the deductibility of interest, (iii) foreign-derived intangible income (FDII) deduction, (iv) state taxes, and (v) a benefit related to the net operating loss carryback allowable under the CARES Act. The Company files income tax returns in the U.S. federal jurisdiction, various foreign jurisdictions, and various state and local jurisdictions where the statutes of limitations generally range from three to five years. As of June 30, 2021, the Company is no longer subject to U.S. federal examinations by tax F-54 ----- authorities for years before tax year 2016. In state and local, and foreign jurisdictions, generally the Company is no longer subject to examinations by tax authorities for years before fiscal 2015. The benefits of tax positions are not recorded unless it is more likely than not that the tax position would be sustained upon challenge by the appropriate tax authorities. Tax benefits that are more likely than not to be sustained are measured at the largest amount of benefit that is cumulatively greater than a 50% likelihood of being realized. On March 31, 2021, the Company acquired 100% of John Herrod and Associates Pty Ltd (“Herrods”), located in Melbourne, Australia, for $19,826 plus net debt assumed of $3,042. Upon closing, $999 of the purchase price was deposited into an escrow account and is to be released to the seller on the 6-month anniversary of the closing date in accordance with the purchase agreement. The escrow amount is to fund certain potential indemnification obligations of the seller with respect to the transaction. Herrods, a leading producer of In-mold labels (IML) in Australia and New Zealand, allows the Company to expand its IML footprint in the Asia Pacific region and complements the Company’s existing IML business currently in Europe and the U.S. The results of Herrods’ operations were included in the Company’s condensed consolidated financial statements beginning on March 31, 2021. The Company is in the process of completing its preliminary purchase price allocation to specific assets and liabilities assumed from Herrods. Throughout 2021, the Company will refine its estimates and assumptions, related to the fair value determination of the acquisition, with the residual of the purchase price in excess of the fair value of assets and liabilities assumed recorded as goodwill. Goodwill arising from the Herrods’ acquisition is not deductible for income tax purposes. The Company spent $645 in acquisition expenses related to the Herrods acquisition. These expenses were recorded in transaction, integration and restructuring costs in the condensed consolidated statements of operations as follows: $435 in the fourth quarter of 2020, $201 in the first quarter of 2021 and $9 in the second quarter of 2021. As a result of our preliminary purchase price accounting and evaluation of fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed, we have preliminarily allocated consideration transferred of $8,544 to separately identifiable intangible assets, $6,099 to property, plant and equipment, $1,817 to operating lease assets, $1,445 to operating lease liabilities assumed, $4,195 to long-term debt assumed, $744 to net working capital assets and liabilities, with the residual consideration transferred of $7,266 allocated to acquired goodwill. On June 24, 2021, LABL signed a definitive agreement to acquire Hexagon Holdings (“Hexagon”), an Auckland, New Zealand-based provider of high-value premium labels. Hexagon is a privately-owned group of businesses producing self-adhesive labels, shrink sleeves, linerless wraps and VIP solutions for clients across Australia and New Zealand. The completion of the transaction remains subject to regulatory approvals, which are expected to be received in the third quarter of 2021.

It is possible that some legal matters for which reserves have or have not been established could result in an unfavorable outcome for the Company and any such unfavorable outcome could be of a material nature or have a material adverse effect on our consolidated financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

The Company receives certain corporate and advisory services from Platinum Equity Advisors, LLC (“Platinum”). Certain funds advised by Platinum indirectly control the Company. These services are provided pursuant to a corporate advisory services agreement between Platinum and the Company. The Company incurred related-party monitoring fee expenses and acquisition and integration related fees, which are included in selling, general and administrative expenses and F-58 ----- transaction, integration and restructuring costs, respectively, in the condensed consolidated statements of operations as follows:

During the three months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, the Company recorded $2,521 and $4,923 in facility closure expenses in the condensed consolidated statement of operations. During the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, the Company recorded $4,856 and $5,861 in facility closure expenses in the condensed consolidated statement of operations. The current year costs primarily consisted of costs related to the closure of our manufacturing facilities in Franklin, PA, Heath, OH, Wilton, NH, Fulton, KY, Vittel, France, one of our facilities in Monterrey, Mexico, the former Tyson Print Shop business located in Springdale, AR and the merger of our facilities in Rawang, Balakong and Kuala Lumpur in Malaysia into one facility. These costs consist of costs to dismantle, transport and reassemble manufacturing equipment that was moved to other facilities, costs to maintain facilities until the building is sold or lease terminated and additional costs incurred as a result of the plant closure. The prior year costs primarily consisted of non-cash fixed asset impairment charges related to the closure of our manufacturing facilities in Franklin, PA, Heath, OH and Rochester, NY of $3,616 and $3,668, which were recorded during the three and six months ended June 30, 2020, respectively. As a result of our decision to close these manufacturing facilities, the Company determined that it was more likely than not that certain fixed assets at these facilities would be sold or otherwise disposed of significantly before the end of their estimated useful lives. The land and building at the Franklin, PA facility were written down to their estimated fair values, less costs to sell, of $1,504, which were determined based on a third-party valuation (a Level 2 measurement). The remaining impairment charges related to fixed assets that were scrapped or abandoned upon closure of the related facility; therefore, the net book values of these fixed assets were written-off. The remaining facility closure costs during the three and six months ended June 30, 2020, respectively, primarily consisted of severance and other termination benefits related to the closure of our manufacturing facilities in Franklin, PA, Heath, OH and Rochester, NY.

The Company has evaluated subsequent events through August 9, 2021, which is the date the unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements were issued. On July 1, 2021, Platinum, the sole stockholder of the Company, entered into a definitive agreement to sell LABL to affiliates of Clayton, Dubilier & Rice (“CD&R”). The proposed transaction is expected to close by the end of calendar 2021, subject to customary regulatory approvals and other conditions. F-59 ----- KPMG LLP Aon Center Suite 5500 200 E. The Board of Directors Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc.:

We have audited the accompanying consolidated financial statements of Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc. and its subsidiaries, which comprise the consolidated balance sheets as of December 31, 2020 and 2019, and the related consolidated statements of operations, comprehensive loss, changes in equity, and cash flows for the years then ended, and the related notes to the consolidated financial statements. _Management’s Responsibility for the Financial Statements_ Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of these consolidated financial statements in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles; this includes the design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and fair presentation of consolidated financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. _Auditors’ Responsibility_ Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits. We conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America. Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free from material misstatement. An audit involves performing procedures to obtain audit evidence about the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements. The procedures selected depend on the auditors’ judgment, including the assessment of the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements, whether due to fraud or error. In making those risk assessments, the auditor considers internal control relevant to the entity’s preparation and fair presentation of the consolidated financial statements in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the entity’s internal control. Accordingly, we express no such opinion. An audit also includes evaluating the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of significant accounting estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall presentation of the consolidated financial statements. KPMG LLP, a Delaware limited liability partnership and a member firm of the KPMG global organization of independent member firms affiliated with KPMG International Limited, a private English company limited by guarantee. F-60 ----- We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion. _Opinion_ In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc. and its subsidiaries as of December 31, 2020 and 2019, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for the years then ended in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. _Emphasis of Matter_ As discussed in Note 2 to the consolidated financial statements, in 2019, the Company adopted new accounting guidance ASU 2014-09 (Topic 606): Revenue from Contracts with Customers. Our opinion is not modified with respect to this matter. Chicago, Illinois April 16, 2021 F-61 -----

Section Title: FORT DEARBORN HOLDING COMPANY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
Subsubsection Text: Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc. (FDC Inc.), a Delaware corporation, along with its primary operating subsidiary, Fort Dearborn Company (FDC or the Company), a Delaware corporation, is a leading supplier of decorative product labels to a wide variety of end markets. The Company manufactures and sells labels for use primarily by the food, beverage, wine and spirits, consumer products, and paint industries. Headquartered in Elk Grove Village, Illinois, the Company has 20 label manufacturing facilities strategically located throughout the United States and Canada.

Section Title: FORT DEARBORN HOLDING COMPANY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
Subsubsection Text: The consolidated financial statements for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, include the accounts of Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc. and its wholly owned subsidiaries: Fort Dearborn Intermediate Holding Company, Inc.; Fort Dearborn Company; Fort Dearborn Company (Brunswick), LLC; FD Alpha Acquisition LLC; FD Alpha Canada Acquisition Inc.; AC Label, LLC; St. Louis Lithographing Company; Core Label, LLC; Southeastern Flexo, LLC; Sleeveco, Inc.; NCL Graphic Specialties, Inc.; Walle Corporation and FD Strongsville, LLC. All intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation. The consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (“GAAP”)

Section Title: FORT DEARBORN HOLDING COMPANY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of the consolidated financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to use statistical analyses, estimates, assumptions, and projections regarding certain types of assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses. Such estimates primarily relate to unsettled transactions and events as of the date of the consolidated financial statements. Accordingly, upon settlement, actual results may differ from estimated amounts. Significant estimates used in the preparation of the financial statements include allowance for doubtful accounts, inventory reserves, impairment of goodwill or long-lived assets, self-insurance accruals, loss contingencies, uncertain tax positions, valuation of deferred tax assets, and allocation of purchase price for acquisitions.

Section Title: FORT DEARBORN HOLDING COMPANY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
Subsubsection Text: The Company considers all highly liquid investments with a maturity of three months or less to be cash equivalents. Cash and cash equivalents include cash on hand and deposits in banks with original maturities of less than 90 days.

Subsubsection Text: In the normal course of business, the Company extends credit to customers that satisfy predefined credit criteria. Section Title: FORT DEARBORN HOLDING COMPANY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
FORT DEARBORN HOLDING COMPANY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
Subsubsection Text: On October 8, 2019, the Company purchased a majority of the assets and the liabilities of Walle Corporation. Walle is a manufacturer of printed labels, principally for the food, beverage, and household, and product industries. The Company has two plant locations, one in New Orleans, LA, which produces Lithographic Cut & Stack Paper and Film labels and In-Mold labels, and a second in Winchester, KY, which produces Flexographic Roll-Fed, and Shrink Sleeve labels. Walle Corporation was acquired for an initial aggregate purchase price of $15,844 which was paid in cash at closing. This acquisition was funded by the issuance of new term debt. Subsequent to closing, the seller agreed to pay the Company a $1,832 working capital adjustment in accordance with the agreement. This is reflected in the financial statements as a receivable in the Other Receivables line of the balance sheet as of December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. In addition, the Company recorded a note payable of $800 to Niagara Bottling, related to pending customer claims outstanding. The purchase accounting was finalized as of September 30, 2020. Subsection Title: (8)** **Revolving Line of Credit and Long-Term Debt
Subsubsection Text: On October 19, 2016, the Company entered into a secured credit facility that provides the company and its subsidiaries with a First and Second Lien loan and revolving line of credit that, when taken together, are referred to as the Credit Facility. Borrowings under the Credit Facility are secured by substantially all of the Company’s assets including inventory and fixed assets. F-77 (Continued) -----

Section Title: FORT DEARBORN HOLDING COMPANY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
Subsubsection Text: The Company leases buildings, machinery and equipment, and computer and office equipment under operating leases expiring in various years through 2032. Lease expense is recognized on a straight-line basis over the life of the operating lease. Rental expense incurred during the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019 was $7,122 and $5,995, respectively. F-79 (Continued) -----

Section Title: FORT DEARBORN HOLDING COMPANY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
FORT DEARBORN HOLDING COMPANY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
Subsubsection Text: The Company sells to a wide variety of customers, both domestically and internationally. During 2020 and 2019 one customer accounted for approximately 6.0% and 6.0%, respectively, of the Company’s total revenues. Accounts receivable balances from this customer were $10,470 and $8,104, respectively, as of December 31, 2020 and 2019.

Section Title: FORT DEARBORN HOLDING COMPANY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, the Company is subject to legal proceedings and other claims arising in the ordinary course of business. The Company believes that there are currently no legal matters that would have a material adverse effect upon the Company’s financial condition or results of operations. The Company maintains insurance coverage against claims in an amount believed to be adequate.

Section Title: FORT DEARBORN HOLDING COMPANY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
Subsubsection Text: On July 31, 2018, the Company’s production facility in Waukesha, Wisconsin was partially destroyed as the result of a fire. The fire caused significant damage to a substantial portion of the assets located at the facility as well as limited production for several months. The Company was able to outsource work to other facilities but was unable to avoid interruptions in production. The Company filed a claim with its insurance provider and settled all remaining asset losses and losses related to business interruption for a total of $2,425 with its insurance provider in 2019. The Waukesha facility was fully restored to operating condition in 2019.

Section Title: FORT DEARBORN HOLDING COMPANY, INC. AND SUBSIDIARIES
Subsubsection Text: In the United States, the Company sponsors a defined contribution plan (the U.S. Plan) to provide substantially all full time salaried and certain full time hourly employees an opportunity to save funds for their retirement. As determined by the provisions of the U.S. Plan, the employees may contribute up to 50% of compensation subject to the maximum contribution limit established by the Internal Revenue Service. The Company will match up to 6.00% of the employee’s salary based on his or her contributions to the U.S. Plan upon completion of the employee’s first year of service. All employees are fully vested upon entrance to the U.S. Plan. For the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019 the Company’s contributions to the U.S. Plan totaled $3,466 and $3,131, respectively. F-83 (Continued) -----

F-67 ----- Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2020 and 2019 Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2020 and 2019 accounts by reviewing and identifying troubled accounts and using historical experience applied to an aging of accounts. The Company writes off trade accounts receivable when they become uncollectible, and payments subsequently received on such receivables are credited to the allowance for doubtful accounts. For the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, the Company had an allowance for doubtful accounts of $3,660 and $1,368, respectively. Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2020 and 2019 Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2020 and 2019 severity, insurance retention levels, the number of incurred but not reported claims, and other factors can materially affect the estimates for these liabilities. Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2020 and 2019 On March 27, 2020 and December 27, 2020, the President of the United States signed and enacted into law the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act) and the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021 (CAA). Among other provisions, the CARES Act and the CAA provide relief to U.S. federal corporate taxpayers through temporary adjustments to net operating loss rules, changes to limitations on interest expense deductibility, and the acceleration of available refunds for minimum tax credit carryforwards. The CARES Act and the CAA did not have a material effect on the Company’s consolidated financial statements. Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2020 and 2019 application on January 1, 2019. The adoption of the standard did not have a material effect on the Company’s financial position or results of operations. The Company sells products that do not have an alternative use, and, under Topic 606, revenue associated with these products is required to be recognized earlier than under prior revenue recognition standards if there is enforceable right to payment in contract. Utilizing the cumulative effect method, the cumulative impact of adopting the new standard resulted in an increase of approximately $1,297 to net sales, $26,603 to receivable, $534 to cost of sales, $352 to accrued expenses and decrease of approximately $14,869 to inventories for the year ended 2019, and $8,117 to opening retained deficit as of January 1, 2019. For the year ending December 31, 2020, the result of adopting Topic 606 was a decrease of approximately $599 to net sales and accounts receivable and a decrease of $905 to cost of sales and increase to inventory, and $150 decrease to accrued expenses as compared with what would have been recognized under Topic 605. The Company recognizes revenue when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists. Our revenue earning activities primarily involve manufacturing products customized for the customer. Revenue from contracts with customers is recognized using a five-step model consisting of the following: (1) identify the contract with a customer; (2) identify the performance obligations in the contract; (3) determine the transaction price; (4) allocate the transaction price to the performance obligations in the contract; and (5) recognize revenue when (or as) the Company satisfies a performance obligation. The Company recognizes revenue for its products when performance obligations under the terms of a contract with a customer are satisfied at a point in time. Revenue is recognized when the product is shipped from our manufacturing facility to our customer. Certain customers may receive volume-based incentives, which are accounted for as variable consideration. We estimate these amounts based on the expected amount to be provided to customers and reduce revenue recognized. Certain customers receive a portion of their products as consigned inventories with revenue recognized once the customer uses or consumes the products. Some contracts with customers contain enforceable right of payment terms that include a reasonable profit throughout the duration of the contract for manufacturing of products that do not have an alternative use, which trigger recognition of revenue over time. The amount of revenue recognized is based on the consideration to which the Company expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services upon completion of manufacturing, including the expected value of variable consideration, based on the completion percentage of products as of the year end. For all sales with an enforceable right to payment and where the products sold have no alternative use, revenue is recognized over time. Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2020 and 2019 During the year ended December 31, 2014, the Company elected to withdraw from both of its U.S. multiemployer pension plans, the Graphic Communications Conference of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters National Pension Fund (GCC IBTNPF), and the Graphic Arts Industry Joint Pension Fund (GAIJPF). As a result, the Company recorded a withdrawal liability calculated from its average contributions over the most recent five years compared to the total contributions to the fund from all employers over the same time period, multiplied by the current unfunded liability. The annual payments required for the GCC IBTNPF and GAIJPF are $345 and $48, respectively, for 20 years. Using a discount rate of 7%, the Company has estimated withdrawal liabilities for the GCC IBTNPF and GAIJPF of $2,868 and $401, respectively as of December 31, 2020. The Company had estimated withdrawal liabilities for the GCC IBTNPF and GAIJPF of $3,007 and $420, respectively as of December 31, 2020 and 2019. As part of the AC Label, LLC acquisition in 2013, the Company assumed a pension withdrawal obligation for a U.S. multiemployer pension plan, the GCC IBTNPF. As a result, the Company recorded a withdrawal liability in purchase accounting that requires annual payments of $128 for 20 years. Using a discount rate of 7%, the Company has estimated withdrawal liabilities for the GCC IBTNPF of $1,062 and $1,114, respectively as of December 31, 2020. Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2020 and 2019 to benefit the Company by creating increased incentives to attract, motivate and aid in the retention of employees who will contribute to the growth and profitability of the organization. The Plan provides long term incentive compensation to the Company’s officers and certain key employees. One half of the granted Incentive Units vest upon the passage of time over five years at a rate of 20% upon each of the first five anniversaries of the original grant date, or upon a change in control. The other half of the granted Incentive Units vest upon the achievement of a predefined return on invested capital achieved by the initial investors. No compensation expense was recognized in 2020 and 2019 from these Units due to the inherent uncertainty in the conditions required to realize such a return as of the financial statement date. The grant date value of all granted Incentive Units was determined by an independent valuation specialist utilizing a Black-Scholes Option Valuation model. Since the Company’s shares are not publicly traded, expected volatility (50%) is estimated based on the average historical volatility of similar entities with publicly traded shares. The risk-free rate of return is based on 5-year U.S. Treasury note yields. Total compensation expense related to the incentive plans was $628 and $866, respectively in 2020 and 2019. As of December 31, 2020 and 2019, the unrecorded compensation cost for the unit awards was $1,338 and $1,744, respectively, and will be recognized over the remaining vesting period for each grant which ranges between 2021 and 2023. These awards are considered equity-based awards and are therefore classified as a component of additional paid-in capital. We have reviewed the accompanying consolidated balance sheet of Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc. and its subsidiaries as of June 30, 2021, the related consolidated statements of operations for the six-month periods ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, and the related consolidated statements of comprehensive loss, changes in equity, and cash flows for the six-month periods ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, and the related notes (collectively referred to as interim financial information). _Management’s Responsibility_ The Company’s management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the interim financial information in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles; this responsibility includes the design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control sufficient to provide a reasonable basis for the preparation and fair presentation of interim financial information in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. _Auditors’ Responsibility_ Our responsibility is to conduct our review in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America applicable to reviews of interim financial information. A review of interim financial information consists principally of applying analytical procedures and making inquiries of persons responsible for financial and accounting matters. It is substantially less in scope than an audit conducted in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America, the objective of which is the expression of an opinion regarding the financial information. Accordingly, we do not express such an opinion. _Conclusion_ Based on our review, we are not aware of any material modifications that should be made to the accompanying interim financial information for it to be in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. Subsection Title: Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc. and Subsidiaries Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Unaudited) (1)** **Overview and Basis of Presentation Description of Business
Subsubsection Text: Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc. (“FDC Inc.”), a Delaware corporation, along with its primary operating subsidiary, Fort Dearborn Company (“FDC” or the “Company”), a Delaware corporation, is a leading supplier of decorative product labels to a wide variety of end markets. The Company manufactures and sells labels for use primarily by the food, beverage, wine and spirits, consumer products, and paint industries. Headquartered in Elk Grove Village, Illinois, FDC Inc. has no additional operations outside of its primary operating subsidiary FDC which has 20 label manufacturing facilities strategically located throughout the United States and Canada. On July 1, 2021, Fortress Parent, LP, a Delaware limited partnership and the parent of FDC, Inc., entered into a stock purchase agreement with an affiliate (“Buyer”) of investment management firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice (“CD&R”) whereby the Company and its affiliates would be acquired and will become an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of the Buyer upon closing of the transaction (the “Proposed Transaction”). The Proposed Transaction is expected to be consummated in late 2021, subject to customary closing conditions, as well as the expiration or termination of the waiting period under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act of 1976.

The process of preparing consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States requires management to use statistical analyses, estimates, assumptions, and projections regarding certain types of assets, liabilities, F-94 -----

The consolidated financial statements as of June 30, 2021 and December 31, 2020 and for the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, present the results of operations, financial position and cash flows of FDC, Inc. and its consolidated subsidiaries prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America. In the opinion of management, the accompanying unaudited consolidated financial statements include all recurring adjustments and normal accruals necessary for a fair statement of the Company’s financial position, results of operations and cash flows for the dates and periods presented. Results for interim periods are not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected during the remainder of the current year or for any future period. Intercompany transactions are eliminated in consolidation. The consolidated balance sheet as of December 31, 2020 is derived from the audited consolidated financial statements but does not include all disclosures required by accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America. This consolidated balance sheet as of December 31, 2020 and the unaudited consolidated financial statements included herein should be read in conjunction with the more detailed audited consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2020. Accounting policies used in the preparation of these unaudited consolidated financial statements are consistent with the accounting policies described in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in the audited consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2020. Certain amounts in the consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 were reclassified to conform with the current year presentation.

Subsection Title: Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc. and Subsidiaries Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Unaudited)
Subsubsection Text: Cash and cash equivalents include cash on hand and deposits in banks with original maturities of less than 90 days.

Subsection Title: Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc. and Subsidiaries Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Unaudited)
Subsubsection Text: The Company is exposed to credit risk in the normal course of business, primarily related to accounts receivable and derivative instruments. Historically, the losses related to credit risk have been immaterial. The Company regularly monitors its credit risk to mitigate the possibility of current and future exposures resulting in a loss. The Company evaluates the creditworthiness of its clients prior to entering into an agreement to provide services and as necessary through the life of the client relationship. The Company’s derivative instruments are recognized as assets or liabilities on the consolidated balance sheets and are measured at fair value at each reporting date. Effective January 4, 2017 the Company entered into two interest rate swap contracts in order to fix the interest rate on a portion of its two debt facilities in which the derivative term matches the loan term on the respective loan. The Company reports separately any gain or loss on its interest rate derivative instruments in the Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Loss. The Company does not believe it is exposed to more than a nominal amount of credit risk in its derivative activities due to the nature of the derivative instruments The Company’s derivative instruments had fair values totaling $1,775 as of June 30, 2021. The derivative instruments expire in January 2022 and are recorded in other current liabilities in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets. As of December 31, 2020, the Company’s derivative instruments had fair values totaling $2,970 and are recorded in other long term liabilities in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.

Subsection Title: Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc. and Subsidiaries Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Unaudited)
Subsubsection Text: In March 2020, the FASB issued ASU 2020-04, Reference Rate Reform (Topic 848): Facilitation of the Effects of Reference Rate Reform on Financial Reporting, which provides temporary optional guidance for a limited time to ease the potential accounting impacts associated with transitioning away from reference rates that are expected to be discontinued, such as the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR). The ASU was effective upon issuance on March 12, 2020. The Company applied certain of the practical expedients as of March 12, 2020 to continue its hedging relationships that reference forecasted transactions based on LIBOR. Optional expedients in Topic 848 are generally available until December 31, 2022. The adoption of ASU 2020-04 did not have a material effect on the Company’s consolidated financial statements. In February 2016, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued Accounting Standards Update (ASU) 2016-02, Leases (Topic 842). The ASU increases transparency and F-95 -----

Subsection Title: Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc. and Subsidiaries Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Unaudited)
Subsubsection Text: The Company recognizes revenue under Accounting Standards Codification (“ASC”) 606 when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists. Our revenue earning activities primarily involve manufacturing products customized for the customer. Revenue from contracts with customers is recognized using a five-step model consisting of the following: (1) identify the contract with a customer; (2) identify the performance obligations in the contract; (3) determine the transaction price; (4) allocate the transaction price to the performance obligations in the contract; and (5) recognize revenue when (or as) the Company satisfies a performance obligation. The Company recognizes revenue for its products when performance obligations under the terms of a contract with a customer are satisfied at a point in time. Revenue is recognized when the product is shipped from our manufacturing facility to our customer. Certain customers may receive volume-based incentives, which are accounted for as variable consideration. We estimate these amounts based on the expected amount to be provided to customers and reduce revenue recognized. Certain customers receive a portion of their products as consigned inventories with revenue recognized once the customer uses or consumes the products. Some contracts with customers contain enforceable right of payment terms that include a reasonable profit throughout the duration of the contract for products that do not have an F-96 -----

Subsection Title: Fort Dearborn Holding Company, Inc. and Subsidiaries Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Unaudited)
Subsubsection Text: During the six months ended June 30, 2021, the Company entered into capital lease arrangements for machinery and equipment for $775 thousand. The term is four years and is secured by the leased assets. The capital lease requires monthly payments of principal and interest of $19 thousand. Additionally, as part of the Hammer acquisition (see note 2), the Company acquired the capital lease of a production facility valued at $9,101 thousand. The remaining lease term is sixteen years. Amortization expense for the acquired capital lease asset was $181 thousand, recognized on a straight-line basis and included in amortization expense in the Consolidated Statement of Operations. Capital leases are included in property, plant and equipment, other current liabilities, and other long-term liabilities in our Consolidated Balance Sheet. Interest expense associated with capital lease liabilities are included in interest expense in the Consolidated Statement of Operations. F-102 -----

In transition, lessees and lessors are required to recognize and measure leases at the beginning of the earliest period presented using a modified retrospective approach. The modified retrospective approach includes a number of optional practical expedients that entities may elect to apply. The Company is currently assessing the impact that adoption of ASU 2016-02 will have on its consolidated financial statements. In December 2019, the FASB issued ASU 2019-12—Income Taxes (Topic 740)—Simplifying the Accounting for Income Taxes, which enhances and simplifies various aspects of the income tax accounting guidance, including requirements such as tax basis step-up in goodwill obtained in a transaction that is not a business combination, ownership changes in investments, and interimperiod accounting for enacted changes in tax law. The ASU is effective for private companies for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2021. The Company is currently assessing the impact that adoption will have on its consolidated financial statements. In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-13—Financial Instruments—Credit Losses (Topic 326)—Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments, and additional changes, modifications, clarifications, or interpretations related to this guidance thereafter, which require a reporting entity to estimate credit losses on certain types of financial instruments, including accounts receivable and funds receivable and seller accounts, and present assets held at amortized cost and available-for-sale debt securities at the amount expected to be collected. The ASU is effective for private companies for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2022. The Company is currently assessing the impact that adoption will have on its consolidated financial statements. alternative use, which trigger recognition of revenue over time. The amount of revenue recognized is based on the consideration to which the Company expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services upon completion of manufacturing, including the expected value of variable consideration, based on the completion percentage of products as of the year end. For consignment and vendor managed inventory arrangements that have enforceable rights to payment and involve products with no alternative use, revenue is recognized over time. All other revenues are considered point in time, with revenue being recognized at a point in time, based on shipments to customers. Shipping and handling costs associated with outbound freight, after control over a product has transferred to a customer, are accounted for as a fulfillment cost and are included in cost of goods sold as incurred. Taxes assessed by a government authority that are both imposed on and concurrent with a specific revenue-producing transaction, that are collected by the Company from a customer, are excluded from sales. (2) **Business Combinations _Oak Printing Company_ On February 2, 2020 the Company purchased the majority of the assets of Oak Printing Company (“seller”), a producer of printed labels principally for the food, beverage, and household product industries for $5,000 thousand in cash. Oak Printing operated one facility located in Strongsville, OH. The acquisition was partially financed via the company’s Revolving Line of Credit. Subsequent to closing, the seller paid the Company a $23 thousand working capital adjustment in accordance with the agreement. The purchase accounting was finalized as of November 30, 2020. The components of the consideration transferred and the amounts recognized as of the acquisition date for each major class of assets acquired and liabilities assumed were as follows (in thousands): utilizes innovative technological solutions through its robust research and development resources. Hammer operates two production facilities located in West Henrietta, NY and Rochester, NY. Total cash paid at acquisition was $100,484 thousand ($101,000 thousand base purchase price). The Hammer transaction is subject to customary representations and warranties, holdbacks, and net working capital adjustment. The acquisition of Hammer was funded through the issuance of new term debt of $90,000 thousand (see note 7) and a capital contribution of $20,000 thousand from the Company’s shareholder. _Preliminary Purchase Consideration Allocation_ The Hammer transaction is accounted for under the acquisition method, which requires the Company to perform an allocation of the preliminary purchase consideration to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed based on their estimated fair values at the date of acquisition. The excess of the preliminary purchase consideration over the estimated fair values is recorded as goodwill. The following table summarizes the Company’s preliminary allocation of the preliminary purchase consideration to assets acquired and liabilities assumed at the Hammer transaction closing date (in thousands): the loan to Hammer under the PPP was forgiven by the lender. The Company did not recognize any gain on extinguishment of this debt, as the seller of Hammer had agreed to indemnify the Company with respect to any portion of this loan which was not forgiven. The Company has excluded the assumed debt as part of purchase consideration allocation. The identifiable intangible assets include Hammer customer relationships of $28,000 thousand and its trademark of $1,800 thousand and have been estimated based on a preliminary valuation and will be amortized over the estimated useful lives of 12 and 0.8 years, respectively. The Company also recognized a preliminary deferred tax liability of $10,977 thousand associated with the transaction, resulting in an increase in goodwill equal to that amount. Preliminary goodwill recognized from the Hammer acquisition is estimated to be attributable, but not limited to, the acquired workforce and expected synergies with the Company. The tax basis of the acquired intangibles and goodwill will not be deductible for income tax purposes. (5) **Goodwill and Other Identifiable Intangible Assets The following is a summary of intangibles (in thousands): (7) **Revolving Line of Credit and Long-Term Debt On October 19, 2016, the Company entered into a secured credit facility that provides the company and its subsidiaries with a First and Second Lien loan and revolving line of credit that, when taken together, are referred to as the Credit Facility. Borrowings under the Credit Facility are secured by substantially all of the company’s assets including inventory and fixed assets. (a) **_Long-Term Debt Long-term debt consisted of the following (in thousands): acquisitions, sell assets and make restricted payments. The credit facilities do not include any ongoing requirements that the Company maintain specific financial performance covenants. If utilization of the revolving credit facility exceeds 35% of the $75,000 thousand commitments, the Company is required to maintain the ratio of Consolidated First Lien debt to Consolidated Adjusted EBITDA (as defined in the agreement) to less than 7.25:1. FDC, Inc. was in compliance with these covenants for the six-month period ended June 30, 2021 and the year ended December 31, 2020. The first lien credit facility requires quarterly payments of principal totaling $1,320 thousand that commenced in March 2017 with the balance due in 2023. Required principal payments are adjusted as additional loan borrowings are made. The second lien credit facility does not have scheduled quarterly principal repayments and comes due in 2024. In addition, FDC, Inc. is required annually to pay a percentage of Excess Cash Flow (as defined by the agreements). The percentage of Excess Cash Flow required to be remitted ranges from 0% to 50% depending on the company’s first lien leverage ratio. FDC, Inc. was not required to make an Excess Cash Flow payment for the six-month period ended June 30, 2021 and the year ended December 31, 2020. (8) **Leases (a) **_Operating Leases The Company leases buildings, machinery and equipment, and computer and office equipment under operating leases expiring in various years through 2032. Lease expense is recognized on a straight-line basis over the life of the operating lease. Rental expense incurred during the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020 was $4,057 thousand and $3,304 thousand, respectively. Certain operating leases provide for renewal options for periods from one month to one year at their current rental value. In the normal course of business, operating leases are generally renewed or replaced by other leases. The following is a schedule by years of future minimum lease payments classified as capital leases with the present value of the net minimum lease payments as of June 30, 2021 (in thousands): approximately 9.4% and 8.5%, respectively, of the Company’s total revenues. Accounts receivable balances (in thousands) from this customer were $9,849 thousand and $10,470 thousand, respectively, as of June 30, 2021 and December 31, 2020. (b) **_Commitments and Contingencies From time to time, the Company is subject to legal proceedings and other claims arising in the ordinary course of business. The Company believes that there are currently no legal matters that would have a material adverse effect upon the Company’s financial condition or results of operations. The Company maintains insurance coverage against claims in an amount believed to be adequate. (11) Stock Option Plan Total compensation expense related to the incentive plans was $336 thousand during the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020. As of June 30, 2021 and December 31, 2020 the unrecorded compensation cost for the unit awards was $1,183 thousand and $1,338 thousand, respectively, and will be recognized over the remaining vesting period for each grant which ranges between 2021 and 2025. These awards are considered equity-based awards and are therefore classified as a component of additional paid-in capital. (12) Related-Party Transactions The Company reimburses Advent International, the Company’s sole shareholder, for reasonable expenses incurred in connection with the business. Total reimbursable expenses paid to Advent International were $55 thousand and $138 thousand, respectively, for the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020. These amounts are included in administrative expenses in the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Operations. On March 1, 2021, Advent International contributed $20,000 thousand as equity financing for the Hammer acquisition (see note 2). From time to time the Company may enter into commercial agreements with subsidiary portfolio companies of Advent International. During the six-month periods ended June 30, 2021 and 2020 revenue associated with these agreements were approximately $1,204 thousand and $1,203 thousand, respectively. (13) Subsequent Events On July 1, 2021, Fortress Parent, LP, a Delaware limited partnership and the parent of FDC, Inc., entered into a stock purchase agreement with an affiliate (“Buyer”) of investment management firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice (“CD&R”) whereby the Company and its affiliates would be acquired and will become an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of the Buyer upon closing of the transaction (the “Proposed Transaction”). The Proposed Transaction is expected to be consummated in late 2021, subject to customary closing conditions, as well as the expiration or termination of the waiting period under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act of 1976. The evaluation of subsequent events was completed through September 1, 2021, the date the consolidated financial statements were available for issuance. (9) **Income Taxes The Company is taxed as a corporation for income tax purposes and is subject to federal, state, and local taxes. Additionally, certain wholly owned entities taxed as corporations are subject to federal, state, and foreign income taxes in the jurisdictions in which they operate, and accruals for such taxes are included in the consolidated financial statements. For the six-month periods ended June 30, 2021 and June 30, 2020, the Company has utilized the discrete effective tax rate method, as allowed by ASC 740-270-30-18, “Income Taxes—Interim Reporting,” to calculate its interim income tax provision. The discrete method is applied when the application of the estimated annual effective tax rate is impractical because it is not possible to reliably estimate the annual effective tax rate. The discrete method treats the year-to-date period as if it was the annual period and determines the income tax expense or benefit on that basis. The Company believes that, at this time, the use of the discrete method is more appropriate than the annual effective tax rate method because small changes in the projected ordinary annual income would result in significant changes in the estimated annual effective rate. Our effective tax rate was 9.4% and 4.5% for the six-month periods ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, respectively. The effective tax rate differed from the federal and state statutory rates primarily due to permanent income tax differences related to goodwill amortization, certain recurring permanent tax differences, and differences in allocable income for the Company’s state tax filings.
